com.hyprmx.android.sdk
Class HyprMXHelper

java.lang.Object
  com.hyprmx.android.sdk.HyprMXHelper

public class HyprMXHelper
extends java.lang.Object

Provides the public interface to the ad request API for performing all HyprMX ad-related functions.

Version:
1.0, 02/23/12
Author:
bjdupuis

HyprMXHelper

Method Detail

getInstance

public static HyprMXHelper getInstance(android.content.Context context,
                                       java.lang.String distributorId,
                                       java.lang.String propertyId,
                                       java.lang.String userId)
                                throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
Returns the singleton instance of the HyprMXHelper for this process. Note that if the application is structured to run in separate Android processes from which HyprMX ad requests are made, each process will have its own independent instance of the HyprMXHelper. The caller is responsible for providing the HyprMX-specified distributor ID and property ID to the API through this method.

Parameters:
context - specifies the context within which to create the instance
distributorId - specifies the distributor ID provided by HyprMX specific to the distributor
propertyId - specifies the application-specific property ID provided by HyprMX
_deviceId - specifies the unique, device-independent identifier for the user. This can be left null in which case a single unique ID will be created internally for the user and will last the lifetime of the installation.
Returns:
the instance to use in future requests
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if context, distributorId or propertyId is null

getInstance

public static HyprMXHelper getInstance()
Can be used to acquire the instance once it has been created. Note that this method _could_ return a null reference if the preceding method had not been used prior to calling this method in the current process.

Returns:
the instance

setHyprMXPriority

public void setHyprMXPriority(HyprMXHelper.HyprMXPriority priority)
Sets the priority at which HyprMX worker threads should execute. Applications that execute continuously in something like an OpenGL surface view or other high CPU-usage environments who find that the default NORMAL priority that the HyprMX layer operates in results in unacceptable delays in loading offers and assets can elect to set a higher priority.

Parameters:
priority - the priority used by worker threads.

getHyprMXPriority

public HyprMXHelper.HyprMXPriority getHyprMXPriority()
Returns the priority at which HyprMX worker threads will execute.

Returns:
the current priority

createButton

public HyprMXButton createButton(android.app.Activity activity,
                                 HyprMXButton.ButtonSize size)
Create a HyprMXButton that can be hosted in a standard Activity and used within the layouts of the Activity. This method is used to dynamically create the button rather define the button in the layout's XML specifically. The content of the returned HyprMXButton will most likely change after initial display to reflect the result from the network request but the size will remain constant after the onMeasure() step.

Parameters:
activity - the Activity within which the button will be hosted
size - the requested size of the button
Returns:
a HyprMXButton containing the ad content and that will launch an offer or offer list selector when clicked
See Also:
HyprMXButton

createButton

public HyprMXButton createButton(android.app.Activity activity,
                                 HyprMXButton.ButtonSize size,
                                 com.hyprmx.android.sdk.api.data.Offer offer)
Create a HyprMXButton that can be hosted in a standard Activity and used within the layouts of the Activity, accepting an optional Offer to show. This method is used to dynamically create the button rather define the button in the layout's XML specifically. This version of the method is an advanced version used by clients who desire more control over which offers are displayed to the user. The provided Offer is displayed within the button, and that Offer is the one displayed when the button is clicked. The following example shows the creation and dynamic insertion of a HyprMXButton into a LinearLayout owned by the Activity. We assume we receive an interesting Offer from whoever invoked us. 
  public class MyActivity extends HyprMXActivity {
  
        @Override
        protected void onCreate(Bundle savedInstanceState) {
                super.onCreate(savedInstanceState);
                setContentView(R.layout.main);
 
                if(getIntent().hasExtra("offer")) {
                        Offer offer = (Offer)getIntent().getSerializableExtra("offer");
 
                        HyprMXHelper helper = HyprMXHelper.getInstance();
                        HyprMXButton button = helper.createButton(this, offer);
                        
                        FrameLayout buttonHolder = (FrameLayout)findViewById(R.id.button_holder);
                        buttonHolder.addView(button);
                }
        }
 
        @Override
        public void onOfferCompleted(HyprMXOffer offer) {
                // do something on complete
        }
 
  @Override
        public void onOfferCancelled(HyprMXOffer offer) {
                // do something on cancel
        }
 
        @Override
        public void onNoContentAvailable() {
                // possibly do something if no content is available
        }
 
        @Override
        public void onUserOptedOut() {
                // possibly do something if user has opted out
        }

Parameters:
activity - the Activity within which the button will be hosted
size - the requested size of the button
offer - the Offer to be displayed. Can be null in which case the standard network endpoints will be hit to determine the content of the button.
Returns:
a HyprMXButton containing the ad content and that will launch an offer or offer list selector when clicked
See Also:
HyprMXButton

createBanner

public HyprMXBanner createBanner(android.app.Activity activity)
Create a HyprMXBanner that can be hosted in a standard Activity and used within the layouts of the Activity. This method is used to dynamically create the banner rather define the banner in the layout's XML specifically. The HyprMXBanner will determine the appropriate size to request and display based on the parent's layout parameters, the amount of space available and the display orientation. The content of the returned HyprMXBanner will most likely change after initial display to reflect the result from the network request but the size will remain constant after the onMeasure() step.

Parameters:
activity - the Activity within which the banner will be hosted.
Returns:
a HyprMXBanner containing the ad content and that will launch an offer or offer list selector when clicked
See Also:
HyprMXBanner

createBanner

public HyprMXBanner createBanner(android.app.Activity activity,
                                 com.hyprmx.android.sdk.api.data.Offer offer)
Create a HyprMXBanner that can be hosted in a standard Activity and used within the layouts of the Activity, accepting an optional Offer to show. This method is used to dynamically create the banner rather define the banner in the layout's XML specifically. This version of the method is an advanced version used by clients who desire more control over which offers are displayed to the user. The provided Offer is displayed within the banner, and that Offer is the one displayed when the banner is clicked. The following example shows the creation and dynamic insertion of a HyprMXBanner into a LinearLayout owned by the Activity. We assume we receive an interesting Offer from whoever invoked us. 
  public class MyActivity extends HyprMXActivity {
  
        @Override
        protected void onCreate(Bundle savedInstanceState) {
                super.onCreate(savedInstanceState);
                setContentView(R.layout.main);
 
                if(getIntent().hasExtra("offer")) {
                        Offer offer = (Offer)getIntent().getSerializableExtra("offer");
 
                        HyprMXHelper helper = HyprMXHelper.getInstance();
                        HyprMXBanner banner = helper.createBanner(this, offer);
                        
                        FrameLayout bannerHolder = (FrameLayout)findViewById(R.id.banner_holder);
                        bannerHolder.addView(banner);
                }
        }
 
        @Override
        public void onOfferCompleted(HyprMXOffer offer) {
                // do something on complete
        }
 
  @Override
        public void onOfferCancelled(HyprMXOffer offer) {
                // do something on cancel
        }
 
        @Override
        public void onNoContentAvailable() {
                // possibly do something if no content is available
        }
 
        @Override
        public void onUserOptedOut() {
                // possibly do something if user has opted out
        }

Parameters:
activity - the Activity within which the banner will be hosted.
offer - the Offer to be displayed. Can be null in which case the standard network endpoints will be hit to determine the content of the banner.
Returns:
a HyprMXBanner containing the ad content and that will launch an offer or offer list selector when clicked
See Also:
HyprMXBanner, Offer

displaySplashScreen

public void displaySplashScreen(android.app.Activity activity)
Displays a full size splash screen over the existing activity. Tapping on the cancel or opt-out button will dismiss the splash screen without proceeding any further with the offer flow. The calling Activity -- or the Activity in the backstack immediately preceding the splash screen -- will have its onPause() method called immediately prior to the splash screen being displayed, and will have its onResume() method called once the splash screen is dismissed and the Activity is prepared to display its content again. As such, those wishing to implement a splash screen into their Activity lifecycle should either display the splash screen from the onStart() method or, if onResume() is the desired lifecycle entry point, should wrap the call in checks to ensure appropriate behavior. Any listener callbacks will be invoked before the onResume() method of the Activity class is called. The following example shows how to display a splash screen from a Activity from the onStart() entry point. 
 
 @Override
 protected void onStart() {
        super.onStart();
 
        HyprMXHelper helper = HyprMXHelper.getInstance();
        helper.displaySplashScreen(this);
 }

Parameters:
activity - the Activity within which the button will be hosted.

displaySplashScreen

public void displaySplashScreen(android.app.Activity activity,
                                com.hyprmx.android.sdk.api.data.Offer offer)
Displays a full size splash screen over the existing activity displaying the provided Offer. This is a more advanced method for use by clients wanting more control over the offer to be displayed. Tapping on the cancel or dismiss button will dismiss the splash screen without proceeding any further with the offer flow. The calling Activity -- or the Activity in the backstack immediately preceding the splash screen -- will have its onPause() method called immediately prior to the splash screen being displayed, and will have its onResume() method called once the splash screen is dismissed and the Activity is prepared to display its content again. As such, those wishing to implement a splash screen into their Activity lifecycle should either display the splash screen from the onStart() method or, if onResume() is the desired lifecycle entry point, should wrap the call in checks to ensure appropriate behavior. Any listener callbacks will be invoked before the onResume() method of the Activity class is called. The following example shows how to display a splash screen from an Activity from the onStart() entry point. 
 
  ...
  List offers;
  
        @Override
        protected void onStart() {
                super.onStart();
 
                HyprMXHelper helper = HyprMXHelper.getInstance();
                helper.displaySplashScreen(this, offers.get(0));
        }

Parameters:
activity - the Activity providing the Context for the splash screen.
offer - the offer to be presented to the user.
See Also:
* @see Offer

displayOfferList

public boolean displayOfferList(android.app.Activity activity,
                                java.util.ArrayList<com.hyprmx.android.sdk.api.data.Offer> offers)
Displays a complete list of Offer objects where the user can select an Offer and progress through the offer flow. The calling Activity -- or the Activity in the backstack immediately preceding the splash screen -- will have its onPause() method called immediately prior to the offer list being displayed, and will have its onResume() method called once the offer list is dismissed and the Activity is prepared to display its content again. As such, those wishing to implement an offer list into their Activity lifecycle should either not invoke the method from onResume() or should wrap the invocation in checks to ensure the offer list is only displayed the desired number of times. Any listener callbacks will be invoked before the onResume() method of the Activity class is called. The following example shows how to display an offer list from an Activity from the onStart() entry point.

Parameters:
activity - the Activity that provides the Context for the offer list
offers - an optional list of offers with which to populate the offer list
Returns:
true if an offer list can be displayed, false otherwise

displayOffer

public void displayOffer(android.app.Activity activity,
                         com.hyprmx.android.sdk.api.data.Offer offer)
Displays a particular Offer. The calling Activity will have its onPause() method called immediately prior to the offer being displayed, and will have its onResume() method called once the offer flow is completed and the Activity is prepared to display its content again. Any listener callbacks will be invoked before the onResume() method of the Activity class is called.

Parameters:
activity - the Activity that provides the Context for the offer
offer - the Offer to be presented to the user.

getOffersSynchronous

public java.util.List<com.hyprmx.android.sdk.api.data.Offer> getOffersSynchronous(android.content.Context context)
                                                                           throws HyprMXHelper.HyprMXThrowable
Returns a list of valid Offer objects retrieved from the HyprMX API. Note that this is a synchronous call and as such MUST not be called from the UI thread. Any attempt to do so will result in an InvalidThreadException being thrown. An example of how to call this function from a Thread appears below. 
        Runnable runnable = new Runnable() {
                @Override
                public void run() {
                        HyprMXHelper helper = HyprMXHelper.getInstance();
                        try {
                                MyActivity.this.offers = helper.getOffersSynchronous(context);
                        } catch (InvalidThreadException e) {
                                // we'll be fine
                        }
                }
                }
        };
        Thread offersThread = new Thread(runnable);
        offersThread.setName("GetOffers");
        offersThread.start();

Parameters:
context - the context from which to execute
Returns:
a List containing the Offer objects retrieved from the API. If no offers could be loaded, an empty list will be returned.
Throws:
HyprMXHelper.InvalidThreadException - if called from the UI thread
HyprMXHelper.OfferListRequestCancelled - if the request is cancelled during execution
HyprMXHelper.OfferListRequestFailure - if the request fails
HyprMXHelper.HyprMXThrowable
See Also:
Offer

processActivityResult

public static void processActivityResult(android.app.Activity activity,
                                         int requestCode,
                                         int resultCode,
                                         android.content.Intent data,
                                         HyprMXHelper.HyprMXListener listener)
Convenience function for users who don't wish to extend the HyprMXActivity class to easily parse the Intent that is produced when offers are possibly presented. The HyprMXListener callbacks will be called from within this method if the activity result is from a HyprMX request.

Parameters:
requestCode -
resultCode -
data -
listener -

setRequiredInformation

public void setRequiredInformation(java.util.HashMap<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> info)
This function allows you to set additional user information that may be known. Information that is set here will be sent on the next request.

Parameters:
info - A HashMap of key/values to add to the required information.
